body_text.text: Clinical presentation of COVID-19 was similar in both groups, and was 25 characterized by fever (55%), non-productive cough (64%), dyspnea (49%), 26 gastrointestinal symptoms (28%) and asthenia/myalgias (19%). Median time (IQR) to 27 diagnosis from the onset of symptoms was 1 day (1-3) in the dialysis group and 3 days 28

(1-7) in KT recipients. The most frequent biochemical findings (in both groups) 29 included mild to moderate lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) elevation, high C-reactive 30 protein (CRP), D-dimer elevation, and a moderate decrease in the lymphocyte count. 31

Sixty-nine percent of KT patients had acute kidney injury on admission. According to 32 AKIN classification, 14/18 (78%) were AKIN 1 and 4/18 (22%) AKIN 2. None of the cases 3 required renal replacement therapy during the observation period. Pneumonia CURB-34 65 and SOAR scores were similar in both groups. Chest X-ray (CXR) showed ground 35 glass opacities in 61% of the cases, alveolar consolidations in 43% and bilateral 36 pulmonary involvement in 65%. 37

Most patients were treated with hydroxychloroquine (92%). In 4 cases (8%), 38 hydroxychloroquine was not prescribed at the physician's discretion due to prolonged 39 QT interval on the initial electrocardiogram. Other therapeutic regimens were added 40 according to clinical course and severity: 37% received lopinavir/ritonavir, 43% 41 received a 3-day course of intravenous steroids (methylprednisolone 0.5mg/kg once or 42 twice daily), 6% received interferon beta 1b, 11% tocilizumab and 11% intravenous 43 immunoglobulin (IVIG). All patients received antibiotics, mainly cephalosporines (61%) 44 and azithromycin (58%). Thirty-three patients (65%) received prophylactic 45 anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin. No thrombotic or hemorrhagic 46 events were observed. Among the KT group, reduction of immunosuppression was 47 performed in the majority of cases: MMF was stopped in 13 cases (50%), tacrolimus in 48 4 (15%) and mTORi in 2 (8%). 49
Although only 8 cases had oxygen saturation ≤90% at presentation, 45/51 50 (88%) required some kind of oxygen therapy in the course of the observation period. 51

During a mean follow-up of 13±7 days of in-hospital stay, 10 patients (40%) in the 52 dialysis group and 10 patients (39%) in the KT group developed acute respiratory 53 distress syndrome (ARDS) and 13 patients (7 on dialysis and 6 KT recipients) eventually 54 died. Patients who developed ARDS presented significant radiologic deterioration 55 within a median time (IQR) from admission of 5 days (3-7). Factors associated with 56 death included: age, higher Charlson comorbidity index, low systolic blood pressure, 57 higher pneumonia severity scores, higher level of CRP, steroid therapy and 58 development of ARDS in the dialysis group (Table 2 ) and oxygen saturation ≤90%, 59 dyspnea on admission, a higher SOAR pneumonia severity score and development of 60 ARDS in KT recipients (Table 3) . By Cox regression analysis, the main determinants of 61 death in the whole study group are shown in Table 4 . 62

All cases were admitted to the floor from the emergency department. Although 63 some cases met criteria for ICU admission, none of the patients was accepted due to 64 capacity constraints. At the end of the observation period, 14 patients (7 dialysis 65 patients and 7 KT recipients) were discharged from hospital.

In this study, we present early clinical course and outcomes of patients with 68 end-stage renal disease on dialysis and kidney transplantation who developed severe 69 acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection and required in-70 hospital management. Although clinical presentation was similar compared to the 71 general population [3, 4] , KT patients seem to present with less fever and more 72 gastrointestinal symptoms (Table 1) . Additionally, compared to previous reports where 73 the majority of patients on dialysis reported no obvious symptoms [5] , fever and 74 respiratory symptoms were common in our dialysis group. On the other hand, COVID-75 19 distinctive biochemical alterations described in early reports from China [4] were 76 comparable to our findings. Elevation of CRP, LDH, D-dimer and lymphopenia were all 77 frequently observed in our study population. Regarding imaging studies, alveolar 78 consolidations were more commonly observed in KT patients. 79

Previous reports suggested that patients on maintenance hemodialysis with 80 SARS-CoV-2 infection presented with mild disease and a favorable outcome [5, 6] , 81 possibly due to a compromised immune system that would hypothetically limit a 82 striking cytokine release [5] . In our experience, this was not the case. Our institution 83 has 208 active hemodialysis patients and 39 peritoneal dialysis patients, of whom 25 84 (10.1%) required hospital admission and 7 (28%) died from direct complications of 85 COVID-19. This mortality was similar to that of a recently published Italian series [10] . 86

We speculate that older age and a high comorbidity burden, well-known risk factors 87 for worse outcomes in COVID-19, might explain the higher mortality observed in our 88 patients. Although steroid therapy was associated with risk of death, this may be due 89 to a selection bias as patients with more severe disease were more likely to receive 90 them. Of note, we have frequently observed poor hemodynamic tolerance during 91 intermittent hemodialysis sessions. 92

In the case of renal transplantation, data regarding SARS-CoV-2 associated 93 lethality is very limited as only case reports and small series have been published to 94 date [7] [8] [9] [10] . Our transplant clinic has approximately 2,500 KT patients in active follow-95 up and less than 1% required hospital admission throughout the study period. Of 96 those, 6/23 (23%) died from direct complications of COVID-19. Although non-97 significant, KT patients who died were numerically older. It is unknown if chronic 98 on interruption of antimetabolites (mycophenolate mofetil/azathioprine) and/or 101 mTORi, reducing tacrolimus dose (25-50%, trough levels 5-6ng/mL) and continue low-102 dose prednisone (2.5-5mg/day). Notably, no rejection episodes or development of 103 donor specific antibodies were observed. 104

Not surprisingly, development of ARDS was a common risk factor for death in 105 both groups. None of the patients was admitted to ICU, therefore; we tempt to 106 speculate that the inability to attain advanced intensive care support could have 107 influence the outcome of some patients who eventually died. However, a recent small 108 series reported variable outcomes in KT patients with COVID-19 that required 109 mechanical ventilation [11] . It is important to point out that results of our multivariate 110 analysis should be interpreted with caution due to the small sample size. Of note, 111 treatment with hydroxychloroquine and prophylactic anticoagulation were more 112 commonly administered in kidney transplant survivors, suggesting a hypothetical 113 protective role in this group (Table 3) . However, due to the retrospective nature of our 114 work and the size of our study population, no causal relationships can be established. 115

In conclusion, this is one of the largest series to report initial clinical 116 presentation and outcomes of COVID-19 in patients with end-stage renal disease and 117 kidney transplantation that required admission. In-hospital mortality in dialysis and 118 kidney transplant patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection was higher than previously 119 reported. Development of ARDS was a risk factor for mortality in both groups. 120
